"Upfront communication is key, inform about location details, so I can prepare how to reach your event." -- @Jusmyk #msts2016

What counts today is the ability to iterate on your product, don't let your ill-guided love to "your" code limit that! #msts2016

To be open means to engage with communities, not just making code available. #msts2016
Openness reduces the onboarding cost for new hires. If they already use your technology, they can start working immediately. #msts2016
There is money in being free. Because you invest in the people maintaining your product. #msts2016
Ask for the social change in your job interviews! You (as developers) have the power to force companies to change! #Diversity

It's fascinating to see that there are 1600+ attendees at a paid (‚Ç¨450) vendor event all week during regular work time.
But independent usergroups whose primary purpose is not enabling sales and lobbying for a specific vendor are never during work-time.
It seems that absence from the primary workplace requires a significant financial investment from the employer to mark it as acceptable.
Which is absurd if you think about it. But so many organizational processes are ‚Ä¶
@AndyScherzinger always!

"Why isn't my computer intelligent?" 
Background on AI in this session. #msts2016 https://t.co/sTPTaDudnU
"Acronyms are no longer hip." #msts2016

AI / ML is simple math. And a lot of computation cycles. 
Training your NL with the right data is actually the hard problem. #msts2016

https://t.co/Q9dHdoDZVU let's you train a speech recognition service with just a few clicks + samples. Result is a REST endpoint. #msts2016

Pretty powerful experience today, enabling a company to understand that #Diversity  is actually worth achieving.
Because everybody has a concrete example where their peers and coworkers will benefit and have suffered in the past for the lack of.
We made them define 3 measures to implement within the next 90 days and all did come up with at least 2.
The outcome of this workshop will affect hundreds of employees, new hires, and also their customers.
Very proud of @RH_Way that we are providing the right, and needed, nudges.

What is your take on the state of enterprise software from a user perspective? I think the "appification" is full on.
Where maybe 10 years back, users would invest time to "learn" a new user interface and functionality because software was seen as something
well worth investing in, because it was there to improve your day-to-day work, and you would accept some of its quirks and awkward UI.
But today, users in general are no longer willing to invest time into learning a new program and its UI features.
They expect simple screens that are self-explanatory and serve one simple goal.
Which is great, because I can now develop the features of a "suite" as independent products, with their own release cycles.
They share a SSO and the same UI paradigmas, but that is easy. As long as you give your users a "home screen" as a starting point,
they will be happily switching between the apps.
This enables you to have the ultimate usability: per use-case, context-sensitive UI instead of compromising for integrating everything.
